name: Adam Kirton
title: Dr.
imageAltText: A white man, smiling confidently in a crisp black shirt, with MRI images in the background
shortDescription: Pediatric Neurologist and director of the BCI4Kids Lab at the Alberta Children's Hospital.

name: Eli Kinney-Lang
title: Dr.
imageAltText: Image of a white man, early 30s, smiling, short brown hair with a beard, in front of a green plant background
shortDescription: Director of Engineering BCI4Kids, Asst Prof. Biomedical Engineering at UofC.
affiliations: Department of Biomedical Engineering, Schulich School of Engineering, University of Calgary, Calgary, Canada
Department of Pediatrics, Cumming School of Medicine, University of Calgary, Calgary, Canada
CEO, BCI Games Inc., Calgary, Canada
labDescription: At the BCI4Kids lab in the BME Program, we aim to translate the evolving brain-computer interface space for children. We are focused on the multitude of digital engineering problems facing BCI translation to children: from digital signal processing, machine learning, and analysis of neurophysiological signals, to the development of engaging, exciting applications for children to play with BCI systems.
currentResearchTopics: Creating engaging applications and games for BCI systems
Structural and functional imaging of children and adults with quadriplegic cerebral palsy (qCP)
Developing engineering solutions for translating implantable BCIs to children with complex needs

name: Mariana Branco
title: Dr.
imageAltText: Image of a white woman smiling, shoulder length brown hair with crossed hands, in front of a railing in a medical building.
shortDescription: Asst Prof. UMC Utrecht Brain Center, Dept. of Neurology & Neurosurgery
affiliations: Department of Neurology and Neurosurgery, UMC Utrecht Brain Center, The Netherlands
labDescription: At the Utrecht-BCI Lab we aim to understand the relationship between electrical, metabolic and cerebrovascular processes of neuronal populations during normal and abnormal behaviour. In addition, we focus on the development of fully implanted home-use Brain-Computer Interfaces for individuals with communication disabilities.
currentResearchTopics: Imaging brains of children and adults with quadriplegic cerebral palsy (qCP)
Identification of needs and interest in BCIs for Cerebral Palsy using user-centered design

name: Helen Carlson
title: Dr.
imageAltText: An image of Dr. Helen Carlson
shortDescription: Associate Professor, Department of Pediatrics, Cumming School of Medicine, University of Calgary
affiliations: Department of Pediatrics, Cumming School of Medicine, University of Calgary
Prediction, Prevention and Interventions on Preterm Birth (P3 Cohort)
CHILD-BRIGHT Strategy for Patient Oriented Research (SPOR) Network
labDescription: My lab uses multimodal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), and electroencephalography (EEG) to investigate neuroplasticity in children with early brain injuries (perinatal/childhood stroke, quadriplegic cerebral palsy, epilepsy, spinal muscular atrophy, preterm birth, traumatic brain injury, chronic pain). We also use personalized neuroimaging techniques to maximise effectiveness of brain stimulation and pediatric brain-computer interfaces (BCIs).
currentResearchTopics: Imaging sensorimotor networks in youth with quadriplegia
